item.title: Palabra del día: ‘homily’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 64 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: homily
item.description: This word has appeared in 64 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: I May Be Free, but the Belarusian People Are Not
item.description: The world must not stop supporting dissidents in Belarus despite the release of some from prison.
item.dc:creator: Ales Bialiatski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Russia Sends Naval Vessel to Escort Oil Tanker U.S. Is Pursuing
item.description: The development deepens the confrontation over the tanker formerly known as the Bella 1, which the United States wants to seize but which Russia has sought to protect.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella, Nicholas Nehamas and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The oil tanker Bella 1 at the Singapore Strait in March. Russia has dispatched at least one naval vessel to meet and escort the tanker, which the U.S. military has been pursuing and trying to seize.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Every Apron Tells a Story at a Tiny Museum
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 7, 2026

item.title: China Touts Hainan, Its Duty-Free Island, Amid $1 Trillion Trade Surplus
item.description: Policies meant to lure importers to Hainan, a resort island off China’s coast, signal an opening up, Beijing says. One expert calls it a “bait and switch.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

media:content.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Visitors at an exhibition center promoting Hainan’s investment opportunities. The island is promoting itself as the world’s largest “free trade port.”

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 7, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 7, 2026.

item.title: Map: 6.4-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes the Philippine Sea
item.description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
item.dc:creator: William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky

item.title: FEMA Staff Bracing for Dismissal of 1,000 Disaster Workers
item.description: The job cuts expected this month are part of a plan by the Homeland Security secretary, Kristi Noem, to remake the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance

media:content.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A FEMA planning document obtained by The New York Times detailed potential cuts of more than 11,500 people from a work force of about 23,000.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for January 7, 2025
item.description: Adrianne Baik gets into character.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Tras la caída de Maduro, el reto de Rubio apenas comienza en Venezuela
item.description: Marco Rubio empujó la ofensiva de Trump que terminó con la captura de Maduro. La nueva meta es forzar concesiones sobre el petróleo para compañías de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Un mal desenlace en Venezuela podría poner en riesgo las aspiraciones del secretario de Estado, Marco Rubio, a un cargo más alto.

item.title: Béla Fleck Withdraws From Kennedy Center Concerts
item.description: “Performing there has become charged and political,” the 18-time Grammy winner said.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:description: Béla Fleck was scheduled to perform in three concerts next month with the National Symphony Orchestra.

item.title: N.Y.C. Child Care Programs Brace for Cuts After Federal Funding Freeze
item.description: The Trump administration said it was placing a hold on $10 billion in subsidies across five states, including New York.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani had a cordial meeting with President Trump shortly after his election, but the administration has now slashed funding to New York State.

item.title: What to Know About the Vaccines Cut From C.D.C. Recommendations
item.description: Federal health officials upended the immunization schedule for American children this week. These are the diseases affected.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Dani Blum and Teddy Rosenbluth

media:content.media:credit: Suzy Allman for The New York Times

item.title: Michael Reagan, a Son of President Reagan Who Fought for Right-Wing Causes, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Reagan, who was the son of Ronald Reagan and his first wife, Jane Wyman, built on his father’s conservative legacy with a radio talk show and columns on right-wing sites like Newsmax.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:description: Michael Reagan, a son of former President Ronald Reagan, speaking at a campaign event for Newt Gingrich in 2012.

item.title: Brain Health Challenge: Workouts to Strengthen Your Brain
item.description: To strengthen your brain, exercise is essential. Today, we’ll help you find a new routine.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: After Trump’s Military Victory in Venezuela, Cuba’s Economy Is in ‘Freefall’
item.description: With widespread power outages, medicine shortages and rising food prices, experts say Cuba’s economy has never been worse, with the crisis coming just as the supply of Venezuelan oil is threatened.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Frances Robles

media:content.media:description: Cooking soup over an open fire in Havana after the failure of a major power plant in October.

item.title: Pardoned Jan. 6 Rioters Rally and Demand More from Trump
item.description: The “J6ers,” as they refer to themselves, praised President Trump but called for more action from his administration, including financial restitution and prison reform.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Protesters marched on the anniversary of Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

item.title: Court Questions Trump Administration Effort to End Temporary Protected Status for Haitians
item.description: A federal judge questioned whether the Trump administration appropriately reviewed safety conditions in Haiti before ending protections for people from the Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:description: Judge Ana C. Reyes faulted the government for “selectively” using a line from a recent U.N. report to justify not extending Temporary Protected Status to Haitians, while ignoring a plethora of concerns laid out in the report about conditions in Haiti.

item.title: U.S. Pressures Venezuela to Expel Advisers From Cuba, China, Russia and Iran
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio was said to have listed the Trump administration’s demands to Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, in a classified meeting Monday with senior congressional leaders.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the Capitol on Monday. He spoke at a classified meeting with senior congressional leaders.

item.title: Entering the Frozen Continent
item.description: As the icebreaker heads into the sea ice zone around Antarctica, penguins and seals start to appear. A scientist on the vessel teaches our climate reporter, Raymond Zhong, to identify different kinds of sea ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, David Seekamp, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Mamdani Issues Executive Orders on Homeless Shelters and City Jails
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani directed city agencies to make plans to comply with rules governing health and safety at the facilities, and said they must work to end solitary confinement.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York said the city must work with the federal monitor overseeing the city’s jails, including the Rikers Island complex, to end solitary confinement.

item.title: Aldrich Ames, C.I.A. Turncoat Who Helped the Soviets, Dies at 84
item.description: As chief of the counterintelligence branch of the C.I.A.’s Soviet division, he had access to some of the nation’s deepest secrets. He had been serving a life sentence since 1994.
item.dc:creator: Tim Weiner

media:content.media:description: Aldrich Ames was led from court in 1994 after pleading guilty to spying for the Soviet Union. He remained in prison for the rest of his life.

item.title: Rubio dice a congresistas que Trump quiere comprar Groenlandia
item.description: Desde su primer mandato, el presidente estadounidense ha dicho que desea adquirir Groenlandia y el lunes pidió a sus ayudantes un plan actulizado para lograrlo. Los líderes europeos expresaron su rechazo.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Ivor Prickett para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Una antigua estación de radar en el este de Groenlandia. El presidente Trump lleva tiempo diciendo que quiere adquirir el territorio.

item.title: Stephen Miller Offers a Strongman’s View of the World
item.description: President Trump’s trusted adviser is casting his hard-right gaze abroad, saying the world must be governed by “force.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

media:content.media:description: Mr. Miller has the president’s complete trust, a staff of over 40 people, and several big jobs that include protecting the homeland and securing territories further afield.

item.title: This Activist Has Long Been Polarizing. Mamdani Is Standing by Her.
item.description: Cea Weaver, a tenant advocate named to a high-profile role in Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s administration, is facing criticism for past comments calling homeownership “a weapon of white supremacy.”
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein, Sally Goldenberg and Mihir Zaveri

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has appointed Cea Weaver, center, as the director of the Mayor’s Office to Protect Tenants.

item.title: Wintry Conditions Cause Hundreds of Flight Cancellations in Amsterdam
item.description: One of Europe’s major travel hubs canceled hundreds of flights this week after days of accumulated ice and snow. More winter weather is expected across Northern Europe through Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:description: Travelers at Amsterdam Airport Schiphol looking for updates on delayed and canceled flights on Tuesday.

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Approved Military Incursion Into Venezuela as Lawful
item.description: The specifics of the memo are unclear. But Attorney General Pam Bondi told lawmakers in briefings this week that the administration would share the document with them.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:description: Nicolás Maduro was escorted off a helicopter to be taken to the federal court appearance in Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: America Is Bad at Accountability
item.description: “The United States has a problem with elite impunity,” says the Opinion columnist Jamelle Bouie, as he looks back on the five years since the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie and Ingrid Holmquist
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

item.title: Rosa von Praunheim, 83, Dies; Captured Gay Life in Germany on Film
item.description: His first feature-length movie, in 1971, was called his country’s “Stonewall moment,” for jump-starting a gay-rights movement. He became a leading voice of it.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: It Is Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, but the Society in Which He Lives (Movie)

media:content.media:credit: Ulrich Heinemann-Rufer/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Rosa von Praunheim in 1972. He was a leading figure within the New German Cinema movement.

item.title: Michigan City to Pay $3.25 Million After Woman Was Mistakenly Declared Dead
item.description: Timesha Beauchamp, 20, was found alive at a funeral home after she had been pronounced dead during a medical episode in Southfield, Mich. She died weeks later.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

media:content.media:credit: Erica Lattimore/Erica Lattimore through Fieger Law, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A lawyer for the family of Timesha Beauchamp said the city of Southfield had agreed to a settlement over the mistaken declaration of her death in 2020.

item.title: Hilton Drops Bookings for Minnesota Hotel Accused of Turning Away DHS Agents
item.description: The hotel giant said it took “immediate action” against a Hampton Inn near Minneapolis after a video showed a worker declining Department of Homeland Security reservations.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

media:content.media:description: The Hampton Inn Lakeville Minneapolis, which is owned by a franchisee, no longer appears as a booking option on Hilton’s website.

item.title: Venezuelan Leaders Project Independence
item.description: Also, Europe discusses postwar plans for Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Delcy Rodriguez in Caracas yesterday.

item.title: Mamdani Paves ‘The Bump,’ A Troublesome Bike Ramp at the Williamsburg Bridge
item.description: The small but symbolic gesture, at the foot of the Williamsburg Bridge, signals more ambitious street redesign plans from the new mayor.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani underscored a promise to tackle street-level improvements during an appearance on Tuesday.

item.title: Tim Walz Says He Ended Minnesota Governor Run to Shield Residents From Trump
item.description: “I don’t think any governor in history has had to fight a war against the federal government every single day,” Gov. Walz said after ending his re-election bid.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño

media:content.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota at a news conference at the State Capitol on Monday.

item.title: Fire Ravages Los Angeles Motel That Played Supporting Role in Films
item.description: A city commission had just voted to consider the site of the old Hollywood Center Motel, which has long been vacant, for landmark status.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

media:content.media:description: A three-story building dating to 1905 that was part of the Hollywood Center Motel in Los Angeles was torn down after it was badly damaged in a fire on Sunday, the authorities said.

item.title: Ex-Turning Point Leader Gets Probation After Forging Voters’ Names
item.description: Austin Smith resigned from the group founded by Charlie Kirk and suspended his bid for re-election to the Arizona House in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:description: Austin Smith pleaded guilty in November to two criminal counts and admitted that he had submitted fraudulent signatures to state election officials.

item.title: Rubio Tells Lawmakers Trump Wants to Buy Greenland
item.description: President Trump has said since his first term that he wants to acquire Greenland, and he asked aides for an updated plan on Monday. European leaders reject the president’s assertions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A former radar station in eastern Greenland. President Trump has long said he wants to acquire the territory.

item.title: Judge Orders Halligan, a Trump Loyalist, to Explain Why She Has Kept U.S. Attorney Title
item.description: The ruling was the most robust effort to date to press the prosecutor, Lindsey Halligan, on why she has continued to serve as the U.S. attorney, despite an order throwing out her appointment.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:description: A federal judge ordered Lindsey Halligan to explain why she continued to lay claim to her title after a different judge had determined that she was unlawfully appointed.

item.title: Suspect in Brown and M.I.T. Killings Discussed Attacks in Videos, Officials Say
item.description: Claudio Neves Valente, who is accused of killing two students at Brown and an M.I.T. professor, left rambling descriptions of the shootings.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial outside the Barus and Holley science building at Brown University, where a shooting killed two people.

item.title: ‘Greenland Belongs to Its People,’ European Lawmakers Say
item.description: European leaders and Greenland residents respond to President Trump’s renewed threats to seize Greenland.

media:content.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, greeting Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark before a summit of European leaders at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: The Players to Know in Venezuela’s Leadership
item.description: Since President Trump deposed Nicolás Maduro, his entrenched web of loyalists has appeared to remain intact. Here’s a look at some of the most influential.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar

media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s vice president, was sworn in as interim leader on Monday.

item.title: There Were Good Reasons to Depose Maduro
item.description: But taking Venezuela’s oil while leaving the regime in place weren’t among them.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Venezuela proyectó unidad tras la salida de Maduro
item.description: Se registraron marchas a favor del mandatario depuesto. La líder encargada, Delcy Rodríguez, contradijo al presidente Trump, que afirmó que EE. UU. iba a “manejar” el país.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:description: Venezolanos marchando en una concentración de apoyo a Nicolás Maduro en Caracas el martes.

item.title: Trump Says Venezuela Will Start Handing Over Some Oil to U.S.
item.description: President Trump said Venezuelan officials had agreed to send millions of barrels. It would be their first major concession since the capture of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
